anatthapadasaṃhitā.meaning_2: meaningless sayings; meaningless verses; a hundred meaningless verses
anatthapadasaṃhitā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The term refers to a collection or compilation (saṃhitā) of unbeneficial or meaningless words/verses (anatthapada), as used in the contexts of sayings, verses, or specifically a hundred such verses.

māhā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Māhā is an indeclinable adverb commonly used in Pāḷi to intensify adjectives or indicate degree, as in 'greatly' or 'very'. Without context sentences, the precise usage cannot be further specified.

cakkhupālattheravatthu.meaning_2: story of the elder Cakkhupāla; case of the elder Cakkhupāla
cakkhupālattheravatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a narrative section in the Theragāthā or related texts, recounting the life and attainment of the arahant monk Cakkhupāla, known for his story of enduring pain during meditation.

maṭṭhakuṇḍalīvatthu.meaning_2: story of Maṭṭhakuṇḍalī; case of Maṭṭhakuṇḍalī
maṭṭhakuṇḍalīvatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a Jātaka story (no. 512) about a young man named Maṭṭhakuṇḍalī who attains enlightenment through devotion to the Buddha. The compound describes the narrative or case centered on this figure, with 'vatthu' indicating a story or instance in Buddhist texts.

tissattheravatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound serving as the title of a specific narrative or legal case in the Vinaya Piṭaka involving the arahant monk Tissa. The term 'vatthu' indicates a case or story, typical for section headings in Vinaya texts.

kāḷayakkhinīvatthu.meaning_2: Story of the black yakkhinī; case of the black female daemon
kāḷayakkhinīvatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a narrative section in the Pāḷi canon, likely from the Dhammapada Commentary or similar, recounting the episode involving a dark-skinned female yakkha (daemon or spirit). The term 'vatthu' here indicates a story or case example used for moral instruction.

kosambakavatthu.meaning_2: the case (or story) concerning Kosambī; the Kosambī affair
kosambakavatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a section in the Vinaya Piṭaka and Saṃyutta Nikāya, referring to the dispute among monks in Kosambī, a key city in ancient India. In Vinaya context, 'vatthu' denotes a specific case or incident.

mahākāḷattheravatthu.meaning_2: The Case of the Elder Mahākāḷa
mahākāḷattheravatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a story or narrative section in the Vinaya or related texts, referring to an incident or case involving the arahant monk Mahākāḷa, known as an elder (thera).

devadattavatthu.meaning_2: story of Devadatta; case of Devadatta
devadattavatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In Vinaya and Jātaka contexts, vatthu denotes a narrative or case study, often prefixed by the subject's name to indicate the protagonist's story, such as the misdeeds and fate of the monk Devadatta, the Buddha's cousin and antagonist.

nandattheravatthu.meaning_2: story of the elder Nanda; case of the elder Nanda
nandattheravatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound serving as a title for a narrative in the Apadāna or similar text, referring to the story or case involving the elder monk Nanda, one of the Buddha's cousins who attained arahantship.

cundasūkarikavatthu.meaning_2: The Case of Cunda the Pig Butcher
cundasūkarikavatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a story or case in the Vinaya Piṭaka concerning Cunda, identified as the pig butcher, likely referring to the lay disciple who provided the Buddha's last meal, though the epithet sūkarika specifies his occupation in this context.

dhammikaupāsakavatthu.meaning_2: case of the righteous lay disciple
dhammikaupāsakavatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound noun serving as a title for a specific narrative or case in the Vinaya, referring to an instance involving a lay disciple characterized by righteousness or adherence to the Dhamma.

sumanadevīvatthu.meaning_2: story of Sumanā the goddess; case of Sumanā the goddess
sumanadevīvatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a narrative in the Apadāna or similar text, referring to the story or case concerning the goddess Sumanā, where sumanā is a feminine name meaning 'good mind' or 'jasmine', devī means 'goddess', and vatthu indicates the 'story' or 'case' in the context of vinaya or biographical accounts.

dvesahāyakabhikkhuvatthu.meaning_2: The Case of the Two Companion Monks
dvesahāyakabhikkhuvatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound functioning as the title of a Vinaya story, where 'vatthu' indicates a narrative case or incident involving two monk companions.

sāmāvatīvatthu.meaning_2: Story of Sāmāvatī; case concerning Sāmāvatī
sāmāvatīvatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a narrative chapter in the Dhammapada-aṭṭhakathā, recounting the story of Sāmāvatī, a chief lay disciple of the Buddha known for her loving-kindness. In Vinaya and commentarial contexts, terms ending in 'vatthu' denote specific cases or stories.

kumbaghosakaseṭṭhivatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound serving as the title of a specific case (vatthu) in the Vinaya Piṭaka, likely involving a merchant (seṭṭhi) associated with pottery (kumbaghosaka, where kumba = pot and ghosaka = seller).

cūḷapanthakavatthu.meaning_2: story; case; example; instance; lit. ground
cūḷapanthakavatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a specific narrative in the Theragāthā commentary or similar collection, recounting the life and attainment of the arahant Cūḷapanthaka, who was foremost among the Buddha's disciples in creating a mind-made body.

bālanakkhattasaṅghuṭṭhavatthu.meaning_2: case of the fool's constellation being lauded by the community
bālanakkhattasaṅghuṭṭhavatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound functioning as a title for a Vinaya case (vatthu) involving a foolish person (bāla), a constellation or astrological matter (nakkhatta), and the community (saṅgha) lauding or serenading it (saṅghuṭṭha from saṃ + √ghus). The form saṅghuṭṭha likely derives from saṅgha + uṭṭhita (arisen or performed by the community), indicating communal praise or ritual.

pamattāpamattadvesahāyakabhikkhuvatthu.meaning_2: case of the monk with two friends who are heedless and attentive
pamattāpamattadvesahāyakabhikkhuvatthu.family_compound: pamatta pamatta dve sahāyaka bhikkhu vatthu
pamattāpamattadvesahāyakabhikkhuvatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a Vinaya case or story involving a monk (bhikkhu) who has two companions (dve sahāyaka): one heedless (pamatta) and one attentive (apamatta). The repetition of pamatta may be for emphasis or stylistic reasons in the compound.

maghavatthu.meaning_2: case of Magha; story concerning Magha
maghavatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Maghavatthu refers to a narrative or legal case involving Magha, the human who became Sakka (Indra) due to his meritorious deeds; in Vinaya context, it denotes a specific case or story exemplifying a rule or precedent.

aññatarabhikkhuvatthu.meaning_2: case of a certain monk; story of a certain monk
aññatarabhikkhuvatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound noun commonly used in Vinaya and Sutta texts to introduce a narrative or case study involving a specific, unnamed monk. The term 'vatthu' here specifically denotes a 'case' or 'story' in the context of monastic rules or examples.

nigamavāsitissattheravatthu.meaning_2: Case of the Elder Tissa who lived in a town
nigamavāsitissattheravatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a story or case in the Vinaya Piṭaka, referring to an incident involving the Venerable Tissa, a town-dwelling elder monk. The compound follows the standard pattern for vatthu-titles in the Theragāthā commentaries or Vinaya sections, where vatthu denotes a narrative 'case' or 'story'.

meghiyattheravatthu.meaning_2: story of the elder Meghiya; case of the elder Meghiya
meghiyattheravatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound referring to a narrative or case in the Pāli Canon (specifically in the Aṅguttara Nikāya or related suttas) about the monk Meghiya, an arahant and attendant of the Buddha, known for his story involving temptation by Māra and attaining enlightenment.

aññataraukkaṇṭhitabhikkhuvatthu.meaning_2: case of a certain monk who was fed up
aññataraukkaṇṭhitabhikkhuvatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a Vinaya story or case concerning a particular monk who became dissatisfied or annoyed, likely in the context of monastic rules and procedures.

saṅgharakkhitabhāgineyyattheravatthu.meaning_2: case of the elder thera who is the nephew of Saṅgharakkhita
saṅgharakkhitabhāgineyyattheravatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a Vinaya story or case concerning a senior monk (thera) who is the nephew (bhāgineyya) of Saṅgharakkhita, a common monk's name meaning 'protected by the community'. In Vinaya contexts, -vatthu denotes a narrative case or example.

cittahatthattheravatthu.meaning_2: story of the elder Citta the elephant's hand
cittahatthattheravatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a narrative or case story in the Vinaya or related texts, referring to an incident involving the elder monk Citta Hatthisāriputta, where 'hatthattha' indicates 'death at the hand of' or 'end by the hand of' an elephant (hatthi, though not explicit in the compound, is implied by the name and context).

pañcasatabhikkhuvatthu.meaning_2: The Case of the Five Hundred Monks
pañcasatabhikkhuvatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound noun used as a title for a narrative or story in the Vinaya Piṭaka, specifically referring to an incident or case involving five hundred monks.

pūtigattatissattheravatthu.meaning_2: Story of the Elder Tissa of the Putrid Limbs; Case of the Elder Tissa with Rotten Body Parts
pūtigattatissattheravatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a narrative in the Dhammapada Commentary or similar collection, recounting the story of the arahant monk Tissa who suffered from a severe skin disease causing his limbs to become putrid and foul-smelling, yet he remained steadfast in his practice.

nandagopālakavatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound noun used as a title for a story or case in the Vinaya, referring to the narrative involving Nanda, the cowherd, likely the one who rejoiced or was happy in his role.

soreyyavatthu.meaning_2: case of the town of Soreyya; affair concerning Soreyya
soreyyavatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] As a compound ending in vatthu in a Vinaya context, it refers to a legal case or matter involving the town named Soreyya, derived from sūriya 'sun'.

pathavikathāpasutapañcasatabhikkhuvatthu.meaning_2: The Case of the Five Hundred Monks Engrossed in Earthly Discussions
pathavikathāpasutapañcasatabhikkhuvatthu.family_compound: pathavī kathā pasuta pañcasata bhikkhu vatthu
pathavikathāpasutapañcasatabhikkhuvatthu.construction: pathavī + kathā + pasut + a + pañca + sata + bhikkhu + vatthu
pathavikathāpasutapañcasatabhikkhuvatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a complex tatpuruṣa compound serving as a title for a Vinaya story involving five hundred monks who were deeply engaged in worldly (earth-related) conversations or discourses, highlighting a case or incident (vatthu) in the monastic rules.

marīcikammaṭṭhānikabhikkhuvatthu.meaning_2: case of the monk practising the mirage meditation subject
marīcikammaṭṭhānikabhikkhuvatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound serving as a title for a Vinaya case involving a monk who practices meditation on the mirage (marīci-kammaṭṭhāna), likely referring to a specific illusory or deceptive practice.

viṭaṭūbhavatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a compound noun referring to a specific case or story involving Viṭaṭūbha, the general of King Pasenadi, likely in a Vinaya or narrative context as indicated by the 'vatthu' element.

patipūjikakumārivatthu.meaning_2: case of the maiden who gives alms
patipūjikakumārivatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a story in the Vinaya Piṭaka, referring to an incident involving a young girl who performs alms-giving or offerings.

macchariyakosiyaseṭṭhivatthu.meaning_2: case of the stingy silk merchant
macchariyakosiyaseṭṭhivatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound functioning as a title for a narrative case in the Vinaya, where 'vatthu' indicates a story or incident involving a stingy (macchariya) merchant (seṭṭhi) associated with silk (kosiya).

pāveyyaājīvakavatthu.meaning_2: case of the Ājīvaka who would go to Pāvā
pāveyyaājīvakavatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound noun serving as a title for a specific case or story in the Vinaya, involving an Ājīvaka ascetic who would or should go to the city of Pāvā.

chattapāṇiupāsakavatthu.meaning_2: The Case of the Lay Disciple with Sunshade in Hand
chattapāṇiupāsakavatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound noun serving as the title of a Vinaya story or case involving a lay disciple (upāsaka) characterized by carrying a sunshade or umbrella (chattapāṇī). In Vinaya texts, such vatthu compounds denote narrative sections recounting specific incidents or rules.

ānandattherapañhavatthu.meaning_2: The Case of the Questions of Elder Ānanda
ānandattherapañhavatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound noun serving as the title of a section in the Vinaya Piṭaka, specifically the 'Questions of Ānanda' chapter. The term 'vatthu' in Vinaya contexts denotes a narrative case or story, here involving questions posed by or to Elder Ānanda.

mahākassapattherapiṇḍapātadinnavatthu.meaning_2: The Case of Almsfood Given to Elder Mahākassapa
mahākassapattherapiṇḍapātadinnavatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound noun serving as a title for a narrative section in the Vinaya Piṭaka, describing an incident involving almsfood offered to the elder monk Mahākassapa, one of the Buddha's chief disciples renowned for asceticism.

godhikattheraparinibbānavatthu.meaning_2: The Case of the Elder Godhika's Final Emancipation
godhikattheraparinibbānavatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a story in the Sutta Piṭaka (SN 21.1) recounting the final passing away of the arahant monk Godhika, who attained parinibbāna after overcoming Mara’s attempts to disrupt his concentration.

garahadinnavatthu.meaning_2: case of blame for giving; case of criticism for offering
garahadinnavatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound noun used in Vinaya texts to denote a specific case or story involving blame for giving, likely in the context of monastic rules where offerings are criticized or prohibited.

aññatarapurisavatthu.meaning_2: story of a certain person; case of a certain man
aññatarapurisavatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound noun used as a title for a narrative or example in the Vinaya, indicating a specific instance or story involving a certain individual.

mahākassapasaddhivihārikavatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound noun functioning as the title of a specific narrative or case in the Vinaya Piṭaka, focusing on an incident involving Mahākassapa and his co-resident monk. The term 'vatthu' in Vinaya contexts denotes a 'case' or 'story' illustrating a rule or event.

ānandaseṭṭhivatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound functioning as the title of a story or case in the Vinaya, involving Ānanda, the Buddha's attendant, and a wealthy merchant (seṭṭhi).

gaṇṭhibhedakacoravatthu.meaning_2: case of the thief who breaks knots
gaṇṭhibhedakacoravatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound used in Vinaya context to denote a specific legal case involving a thief who breaks knots, likely referring to a story or incident in the monastic code.

udāyittheravatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a narrative section in the Vinaya Piṭaka or related texts, referring to the story or case involving the elder monk Udāyī, likely one of the monks named such as Kāḷudāyī or Paṇḍitāudāyī.

tiṃsapāveyyakabhikkhuvatthu.meaning_2: The Case of the Thirty Monks from Pāvā
tiṃsapāveyyakabhikkhuvatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a title of a Vinaya story or case involving thirty monks originating from or residing in the town of Pāvā.

suppabuddhakuṭṭhivatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a Vinaya story (vatthu) involving Suppabuddha, a leper who was well-awakened, likely referring to his enlightenment or awakening despite his condition.

kassakavatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In Vinaya context, 'vatthu' denotes a case or story, here referring to the case involving a farmer.

sumanamālākāravatthu.meaning_2: case of the garland maker of jasmine; story of the florist
sumanamālākāravatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a story in the Vinaya, referring to the case or narrative involving a florist who makes garlands from jasmine flowers.

uppalavaṇṇattherīvatthu.meaning_2: story of the elder nun Uppalavaṇṇā; case of the elder nun Uppalavaṇṇā
uppalavaṇṇattherīvatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a narrative section in the Therīgāthā or Apadāna, recounting the life and attainment of arahantship by the nun Uppalavaṇṇā, known for her supernatural powers including the ability to vanish and reappear at will.

madhuṃvā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, madhuṃ is the accusative singular of madhu, used metaphorically to mean 'sweetness' or 'something pleasant'. The fool perceives evil (pāpaṃ) as sweet, implying a misguided attraction to wrongdoing.
madhuṃvā.translation_1: The fool imagines that evil is sweet,

jambukattheravatthu.meaning_2: story of the elder Jambuka; case of the elder Jambuka
jambukattheravatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound serving as the title of a narrative section in the Pāli canon, likely from the Apadāna or similar collection, recounting the life or attainment of the arahant monk Jambuka, an elder (thera) known for his ascetic background.

ahipetavatthu.meaning_2: story of the snake ghost; case of the snake ghost
ahipetavatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Refers to a specific narrative or case in the Petavatthu involving a ghost associated with a snake, likely highlighting themes of karma and rebirth.

sajjukhīraṃva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The expression describes something that does not curdle in the same quick manner as milk, using iva for comparison. The accusative khīraṃ is due to the simile construction with iva.
sajjukhīraṃva.translation_1: does not curdle quickly like milk.

cittagahapativatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a section in the Vinaya Piṭaka, referring to a case or story involving Citta the householder, a prominent lay disciple known for his wisdom and generosity.

vanavāsitissasāmaṇeravatthu.meaning_2: Story of the novice Sāmaṇera Tissa who lived in the forest
vanavāsitissasāmaṇeravatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound title for a Vinaya narrative section, where 'vanavāsī' describes the novice named 'Tissa' (a common monk's name), and 'vatthu' indicates the case or story.

rādhattheravatthu.meaning_2: story of the elder Rādha; case of the elder Rādha
rādhattheravatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a narrative section in the Dhammapada Commentary or similar text, recounting the story or case concerning the arahant monk Rādha.

assajipunabbasukavatthu.meaning_2: case of Assaji and Punabbasuka; case concerning the followers of Assaji and Punabbasuka; case of the group of six monks
assajipunabbasukavatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a specific Vinaya case involving Assaji and Punabbasuka, two of the group of six monks, and their followers. As a vatthu in Vinaya context, it denotes a narrative case or story illustrating a monastic rule.

channattheravatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a narrative in the Pāli canon, specifically the story concerning the elder monk Channa, who is known from various suttas and committed suicide as an arahant. 'Channa' here refers to the proper name of the monk (channa 2.3), 'thera' to his senior status (thera 1.2), and 'vatthu' to the story or case (vatthu 4).

mahākappinattheravatthu.meaning_2: story of the elder Mahākappina; case of the elder Mahākappina
mahākappinattheravatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound functioning as the title of a narrative section in the Dhammapada Aṭṭhakathā, recounting the life and enlightenment story of the arahant Mahākappina Thera. In Vinaya and commentarial contexts, vatthu compounds denote specific cases or stories of monks.

paṇḍitasāmaṇeravatthu.meaning_2: story of the wise novice; case of the intelligent novice monk
paṇḍitasāmaṇeravatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a story in the Vinaya Piṭaka or related texts, referring to an incident or case involving a novice monk who is wise or learned.

lakuṇḍakabhaddiyattheravatthu.meaning_2: story of the elder Lakuṇḍakabhaddiya; case of the elder Lakuṇḍakabhaddiya
lakuṇḍakabhaddiyattheravatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a narrative section in the Apadāna or similar text, recounting the story or case of the arahant monk Lakuṇḍakabhaddiya, known as the 'lucky dwarf' elder.

kāṇamātāvatthu.meaning_2: case of the mother of the one-eyed man
kāṇamātāvatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound noun used as a title for a specific case in the Vinaya Piṭaka, referring to an incident involving a lay female disciple known as the 'mother of the one-eyed' person.

dhammikattheravatthu.meaning_2: The Case of the Elder Dhammika
dhammikattheravatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a specific narrative section in the Dhammapada-aṭṭhakathā or similar commentary, recounting the story or case involving the elder monk Dhammika, who is righteous and in accordance with the Dhamma.

dhammassavanattheravatthu.meaning_2: story of the elder for the sake of hearing the Dhamma; case concerning the purpose of listening to a sermon
dhammassavanattheravatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound functioning as a chapter or story title in the Vinaya or Sutta context, where 'vatthu' indicates a narrative case or example involving an elder (thera) motivated by the purpose (attha) of hearing the Dhamma (dhammassavana).

pañcasataāgantukabhikkhuvatthu.meaning_2: case of the five hundred visiting monks
pañcasataāgantukabhikkhuvatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a Vinaya story (vatthu) concerning five hundred (pañcasata) visiting or newcomer (āgantuka) monks (bhikkhu). The compound follows the typical structure for naming cases in the Vinaya Piṭaka.

āyuvaḍḍhanakumāravatthu.meaning_2: The Story of the Long-Life Increasing Prince; The Case of the Prince Who Increases Longevity
āyuvaḍḍhanakumāravatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound functioning as the title of a narrative or case in the Vinaya or similar text, where 'vatthu' indicates a story or instance. 'Āyuvaḍḍhana' likely describes the prince's characteristic of promoting or embodying longevity, combining 'āyu' (long life) and 'vaḍḍhana' (increasing).

khāṇukoṇḍaññattheravatthu.meaning_2: The Case of the Elder Koṇḍañña of Khāṇu
khāṇukoṇḍaññattheravatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a narrative section in the Vinaya Piṭaka, referring to the story or case involving the senior monk Koṇḍañña, associated with the location Khāṇu. Vatthu here denotes a 'case' or 'story' in the Vinaya context.

sabbadāsattheravatthu.meaning_2: The Case of the Always-Weeping Elder
sabbadāsattheravatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a title of a story in the Vinaya, referring to an elder monk who was always crying or weeping (sabbadā ravaṃ atthi). paṭācārātherīvatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a chapter in the Therīgāthā and Apadāna, narrating the life story of Paṭācārā, an eminent bhikkhunī who attained arahantship after profound personal tragedies involving the loss of her family and who became foremost among nuns in knowledge of the monastic discipline.

seyyasakattheravatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a Vinaya story concerning the monk Seyyasaka, notorious for violating Saṅghādisesa 1 (illicit sexual intercourse). 'Vatthu' here indicates a narrative case or incident in the monastic code.

lāḷudāyītheravatthu.meaning_2: the case of the elder Lāḷudāyī

vajiraṃvasmamayaṃ.meaning_1: like a diamond that grinds a stone-made (gem)
vajiraṃvasmamayaṃ.meaning_2: as diamond grinds a lesser gem
vajiraṃvasmamayaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound formed for poetic or metrical purposes, combining 'vajiraṃ' (acc. sg. nt, 'diamond'), 'iva' ('like; as'), and 'asmamayaṃ' (acc. sg. nt, 'made of stone'). In the context of the sentence, it describes the Buddha's teaching as penetrating and effective, akin to how a diamond effortlessly cuts or grinds a harder stone or lesser gem, illustrating the irresistible power of profound insight over ordinary understanding.
vajiraṃvasmamayaṃ.translation_1: as diamond grinds a lesser gem.

accantadussilyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'accantadussilyaṃ' describes a state of being utterly overwhelmed or choked by the deepest level of immoral conduct, as indicated by the English translation 'One choked by immorality'.

noyāti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'jitaṃ yassa noyāti koci loke' means 'whose victory no one in the world leads away' or 'a victory that no one in the world surpasses'. noyāti.translation_1: a victory unrivaled in all the world;

kassapadasabalassasuvaṇṇacetiyavatthu.meaning_2: story concerning the golden shrine site of the slave of the ten-powered Kassapa

māravatthu.meaning_2: domain of Māra; sphere of Māra; case concerning Māra

aṅkuravatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Refers to a specific story or case in the Petavatthu involving Aṅkura, a character whose name literally means 'sprout'. Vatthu here denotes a narrative instance or example.

pañcabhikkhuvatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound noun used in Vinaya texts to denote a specific legal case or story involving five monks. The term 'vatthu' here indicates a narrative case or instance, common in monastic disciplinary contexts.

haṃsaghātakabhikkhuvatthu.meaning_2: Case of the monk who is a swan-slayer
haṃsaghātakabhikkhuvatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a Vinaya story concerning a monk who killed a swan (haṃsa), highlighting a case involving violation of precepts against killing.

kokālikavatthu.meaning_2: case of Kokālika; story of Kokālika
kokālikavatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound functioning as a title for a specific narrative section in the Pāli canon, particularly in the Sutta Nipāta or related texts, recounting the story and fate of the monk Kokālika who slandered Sāriputta and Moggallāna.

dhammārāmattheravatthu.meaning_2: The Case of the Dhamma-Enjoying Elder
dhammārāmattheravatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound noun serving as the title of a specific story or case in the Vinaya, referring to an elder monk who delights in the Dhamma. In Vinaya contexts, terms ending in 'vatthu' denote individual cases or stories.

vipakkhasevakabhikkhuvatthu.meaning_2: case of the monk siding with the enemy
vipakkhasevakabhikkhuvatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a Vinaya case/story involving a monk (bhikkhu) who sides with the enemy (vipakkhasevaka). Vatthu here indicates a narrative instance or legal case in the monastic code.

pañcaggadāyakabrāhmaṇavatthu.meaning_2: The Case of the Brahman Who Gave Five Tops
pañcaggadāyakabrāhmaṇavatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a Vinaya story or case concerning a Brahman donor who offered five supreme items (possibly fruits, flowers, or other gifts). The compound structure indicates a narrative instance (vatthu) focused on the Brahman (brāhmaṇa) characterized as a giver (dāyaka) of five highest/topmost things (pañca agga).

santakāyattheravatthu.meaning_2: the case of the elder with a calm body; story of the elder of the relaxed body
santakāyattheravatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound functioning as a title for a narrative section in the Vinaya, where vatthu indicates a case or story involving the elder (thera) characterized by a calm or relaxed body (santakāya).

naṅgalakulattheravatthu.meaning_2: story of the elder of the plough family
naṅgalakulattheravatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a story in the Dhammapada commentary (Dhammapada-aṭṭhakathā), referring to the narrative concerning the elder monk from the family named Naṅgalakula, literally 'plough family'. In commentarial literature, -vatthu denotes the foundational story or case illustrating a verse.

vakkalittheravatthu.meaning_2: The Case of the Elder Vakkali
vakkalittheravatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a narrative section in the Dhammapada Commentary or similar text, recounting the story or 'case' (vatthu) of the elder monk Vakkali, known for his devotion to the Buddha.

sumanasāmaṇeravatthu.meaning_2: The Case of Sumanasāmaṇera; The Story of the Novice Sumanā
sumanasāmaṇeravatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a story in the Vinaya Piṭaka, referring to the narrative concerning the novice monk named Sumana (lit. 'good mind'), highlighting a specific case or incident involving him.

pasādabahulabrāhmaṇavatthu.meaning_2: story of the faith-abundant Brahman; case of the Brahman full of faith
pasādabahulabrāhmaṇavatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a narrative section in the Vinaya or Sutta Piṭaka, referring to the story or case involving a Brahman characterized by abundant faith (pasāda) and confidence in the Buddha's teachings.

ānandattheravatthu.meaning_2: story of the elder Ānanda; case of the elder Ānanda
ānandattheravatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a narrative section in the Theragāthā commentary, detailing the life and attainments of the elder Ānanda, the Buddha's attendant.

aññatarabrāhmaṇapabbajitavatthu.meaning_2: story of a certain Brahman monk; case of a certain Brahman monk
aññatarabrāhmaṇapabbajitavatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a narrative section in the Vinaya or Sutta Piṭaka, referring to the story or case concerning a particular Brahman who has become a monk. The term 'vatthu' here indicates a narrative instance or legal case in the monastic context.

mahāpajāpatigotamīvatthu.meaning_2: story of Mahāpajāpatigotamī; case of Mahāpajāpatigotamī
mahāpajāpatigotamīvatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a title or chapter heading in the Vinaya or Sutta Piṭaka, referring to the narrative account concerning Mahāpajāpatī Gotamī, the Buddha's stepmother and the first ordained bhikkhunī.

jaṭilabrāhmaṇavatthu.meaning_2: story of the dreadlocked Brahman; case of the dreadlocked Brahman
jaṭilabrāhmaṇavatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a narrative section in the Pāli canon, likely from the Vinaya or Suttas, recounting an encounter or story involving a dreadlocked Brahman ascetic. In the context of vinaya texts, 'vatthu' denotes a case or story serving as an example or basis for rules.

kuhakabrāhmaṇavatthu.meaning_2: story of the deceitful Brahman; case of the fraudulent priest
kuhakabrāhmaṇavatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound serving as the title of a narrative in the Vinaya or Sutta Piṭaka, where vatthu indicates the 'story' or 'case' involving a Brahman characterized by deceit (kuhaka).

ekabrāhmaṇavatthu.meaning_2: story of one Brahman; case of a single Brahman
ekabrāhmaṇavatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a narrative section in the Pāli canon, likely from the Vinaya or Suttas, referring to an incident or story involving a single Brahman. The term 'vatthu' here denotes a 'case' or 'story' in the context of Vinaya-like collections.

uggasenaseṭṭhiputtavatthu.meaning_2: case of Uggasena's son, the wealthy merchant's son
uggasenaseṭṭhiputtavatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound title for a narrative case in the Vinaya Piṭaka involving Uggasena, a layman and banker from Rājagaha, and his son who is a wealthy merchant's son. The term 'vatthu' here specifically denotes a 'case' or 'story' in the context of Vinaya rules and examples.

dvebrāhmaṇavatthu.meaning_2: story of two brahmans; case of two brahmans
dvebrāhmaṇavatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a narrative section in the Pāḷi canon, likely from the Vinaya or Suttas, referring to an account involving two brahmans. In Vinaya contexts, 'vatthu' indicates a case or story exemplifying a rule.

akkosakabhāradvājavatthu.meaning_2: Story of the Insulter Bhāradvāja; case of the insulter Bhāradvāja
akkosakabhāradvājavatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a narrative in the Pāli canon, referring to the story involving a Brahman of the Bhāradvāja family known as the 'insulter' due to his abusive behavior towards the Buddha or monks. In Vinaya contexts, vatthu often denotes a case or incident.

uppalavaṇṇāttherīvatthu.meaning_2: story of the elder nun Uppalavaṇṇā; case of the elder nun Uppalavaṇṇā
uppalavaṇṇāttherīvatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a narrative section in the Therīgāthā or Apadāna, recounting the life and attainment of the arahant nun Uppalavaṇṇā, known for her lotus-like complexion and supernormal powers.

khemābhikkhunīvatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound functioning as a title for a narrative section in the Vinaya or Sutta Piṭaka, specifically the story or account involving the arahant nun Khemā.

pabbhāravāsitissattheravatthu.meaning_1: The Case of the Elder Tissa, Resident at Pabbhāra
pabbhāravāsitissattheravatthu.meaning_2: story; case; example; instance; lit. ground
pabbhāravāsitissattheravatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound serving as the title of a Vinaya story about the Elder Tissa who resided at Pabbhāra, a location likely referring to a mountain slope or overhanging rock site. The term 'vatthu' indicates a narrative case in the Vinaya context.

sāmaṇerānaṃvatthu.meaning_2: story of the novices; case of the novices
sāmaṇerānaṃvatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound functioning as a title for a narrative section in the Vinaya or Sutta Piṭaka, where 'vatthu' specifically denotes a 'story' or 'case' involving the genitive plural 'sāmaṇerānaṃ' (of the novices). The sandhi form 'sāmaṇerānaṃvatthu' merges the final 'ṃ' of the genitive with 'v', but the lemma retains the full form for clarity.

mahāpanthakattheravatthu.meaning_2: story; case; example; instance; case of Mahāpanthaka Thera
mahāpanthakattheravatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a narrative section in the Apadāna or a similar text, recounting the life and attainments of Mahāpanthaka Thera, an eminent arahant disciple renowned for his mastery in meditative perception expansion. The term 'vatthu' here specifically denotes a biographical or exemplary case within the Vinaya or canonical stories.

pilindavacchattheravatthu.meaning_2: story of the elder Pilindavaccha; case of the elder Pilindavaccha
pilindavacchattheravatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a narrative section in the Theragāthā commentary, referring to the story or account concerning the arahant monk Pilindavaccha, known for his abrupt speech.

aññatarattheravatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound functioning as a title for a narrative or account in the Vinaya tradition, specifically 'the case of a certain elder'. The term 'vatthu' in this context indicates a legal or disciplinary story involving the elder.

revatattheravatthu.meaning_2: case of the elder Revata; narrative concerning the monk Revata
revatattheravatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a specific narrative section in the Dhammapada Commentary, focusing on the life and story of Revata, the elder monk renowned for his forest dwelling practices.

candābhattheravatthu.meaning_2: story of the moonlight rice elder; case of the elder who received rice in moonlight
candābhattheravatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a title of a story in the Dhammapada Commentary (Dhammapada-aṭṭhakathā), referring to the tale of the elder monk (thera) who received rice (bhatt) under moonlight (candābhā). In vinaya and commentary contexts, vatthu denotes a narrative case or story.

sīvalittheravatthu.meaning_2: The Case of the Elder Sīvalī
sīvalittheravatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a story or narrative section in the Dhammapada Commentary or similar text, recounting the life and attainments of the arahant Sīvalī, who was preeminent among the Buddha's disciples in receiving gifts and requisites due to his accumulated merit from past lives.

sundarasamuddattheravatthu.meaning_2: Story of the Elder Beautiful Ocean; case of the Elder Sundarasamudda
sundarasamuddattheravatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a narrative in the Apadāna or similar collection, referring to the story or case concerning the arahant monk named Sundarasamudda, meaning 'Beautiful Ocean'.

jaṭilattheravatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound noun serving as a title for a specific case or story involving a dreadlocked ascetic elder, typical in Vinaya contexts where 'vatthu' denotes a case or narrative instance.

jotikattheravatthu.meaning_2: The Case of the Elder Jotika
jotikattheravatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a story or case in the Vinaya, referring to the elder monk named Jotika (or possibly the householder Jotika associated with him).

naṭaputtakattheravatthu.meaning_2: story of the elder who was the son of a dancer
naṭaputtakattheravatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a story in the Vinaya or Apadāna collection, referring to the case or narrative of an elder monk whose father was a dancer or actor. 'Puttaka' functions as a diminutive of 'putta' (son), indicating 'little son' or 'young son' in this context.

vaṅgīsattheravatthu.meaning_2: The Case of the Elder Vaṅgīsa; story concerning the elder monk Vaṅgīsa
vaṅgīsattheravatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a specific narrative section in the Sutta Piṭaka, likely within the Saṃyutta Nikāya, recounting an incident or story involving the arahant monk Vaṅgīsa, renowned for his poetic and spontaneous verses.

dhammadinnāttherīvatthu.meaning_2: case of the senior nun Dhammadinnā
dhammadinnāttherīvatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a story or case in the Therīgāthā or Vinaya context, referring to the narrative concerning the arahant nun Dhammadinnā, who is renowned for her deep understanding of the Dhamma.

devahitabrāhmaṇavatthu.meaning_2: story of the Brahman Devahita; case of the Brahman benefactor of the gods
devahitabrāhmaṇavatthu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a specific narrative section in the Pāli canon, likely from the Vinaya or Suttas, recounting an incident involving the Brahman named Devahita, who is characterized as a benefactor of the gods.
